definition: The process of restoring a filesystem to a consistent state after a crash or unexpected shutdown.
A program that is run on bootup to check the filesystem for consistency and repair any problems it can.
A technique that requires making updates in a particular order to prevent certain kinds of inconsistencies.
A technique that involves writing all changes to a log before writing them to the disk, which can help restore the filesystem to a consistent state after a crash.
The ability of a filesystem to maintain data integrity in the face of system crashes and other errors.
The ability of a filesystem to maintain a consistent state across multiple operations.
The ability of a filesystem to execute operations quickly and efficiently.
A technique used to truncate long write-ahead logs.
A property of a log entry that allows it to be applied multiple times without changing the result.
A set of operations that must be performed together in order to maintain data integrity.
The property of a transaction that ensures that either all operations succeed or none of them do.
A technique that requires all writes to be completed before the next operation can begin.
A type of inconsistency that can occur when resources are allocated but not freed.
Operations that modify the structure of the filesystem, such as creating, deleting, and renaming files.
A record of all operations that have been performed, which can be used to restore the filesystem to a consistent state after a crash.
The process of re-executing operations from the paper trail to restore the filesystem to a consistent state after a crash.
A type of hardware failure that can cause data loss or corruption.
The accuracy and consistency of data stored in a filesystem.
The comparison of two or more competing factors in order to determine the optimal solution.
